I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan;  and  (ii)  proposed  administration  of  a  grant  to  be  provided  by  the  Government  of 
New Zealand,  both  to  the  Republic  of  Vanuatu  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Interisland 
Shipping  Support  Project.1 The  need  for  additional  financing  is  due  to  (i)  changes  in  technical 
and  design  specifications  of  certain  wharves  and  jetties;  (ii)  the  government’s  request  for 
changes in scope; and (iii) additional consulting services in connection with the foregoing.   
 
The project will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of interisland shipping services.2 
2. 
This involves (i) the construction and repair of wharves and jetties, with associated facilities, in 
the national capital of Port Vila and five outer islands;3 and (ii) the establishment of a shipping 
support  scheme  (SSS)  to  catalyze  the  provision  of  services  to  remote  noncommercial 
destinations  using  an  output-based  aid  approach.  The  project  is  complemented  by  associated 
technical  assistance  (TA) 4  to 
improve  sector  governance,  and  safety  regulation  and 
enforcement through institutional strengthening and legal and regulatory reforms.5 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
Infrastructure  constraints.  Inadequate  wharves  and  jetties  restrict  the  ability  of 
interisland  vessels  to  call  at  destinations  in  all-weather  conditions.  Restricted  access  causes 
increased  waiting  times  and  costs  and,  in  some  cases,  prevents  vessels  from  reaching  rural 
areas altogether. Poor wharf and jetty facilities create unsafe loading conditions for passengers 
and  loss  of  goods.  Port  Vila  has  insufficient  domestic  berths  and  faces  the  impending  loss  of 
nearly all remaining berths, with potentially severe consequences for national commerce. Out of 
21 wharves and jetties in Vanuatu, 11 are government-owned and the remainder are privately 
owned. Of the 11 government-owned wharves, 60% are in poor condition.     
 
4. 
Service  provision.  Vanuatu  has  a  sufficient  domestic  fleet,  but  services  are  not 
provided to some remote locations as those routes are uneconomical. Shipping services are not 
provided  because  demand  is  uncertain  in  rural  areas,  while  demand  is  not  effectively 
communicated  since  service  provisions  are  uncertain.  Interisland  water  transport  is,  therefore, 
infrequent and unreliable.6  
  
Current  project.  The  current  project  was  approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
5. 
(ADB) Board on 30 November 2011 and was made effective on 6 September 2012. The project 
represented a return to borrowing by the government from ADB after a period of 12–13 years.

Around  the  same  time,  national  elections  were  held  and  accordingly,  it  took  time  for  the  new 
government to get familiarized with ADB processes and complete pre-implementation activities 
which led to some delays in effectivity. 

 
The  current  project  aims  to  build  a  new  interisland  shipping  terminal  in  Port  Vila,  with 
6. 
sufficient  berthing  capacity  to  handle  conventional  vessels  and  landing  crafts  in  the  Vanuatu 
fleet  simultaneously.  To  improve  rural  access,  one  outer  island  wharf  and  three  jetties  will  be 
constructed,  and three existing  outer  island  wharves  will  be  rehabilitated  or  repaired.7 All  sites 
will  have  ancillary  infrastructure,  as  appropriate  for  each  location,  to  cater  to  the  transit  of 
passengers  (including  market  shelters  and  separate  facilities  for  women,  children,  men,  and 
people  with  disabilities)  and  storage  for  cargo  transshipment.  Wharves  and  jetties  will  be 
designed to endure a lifespan of 50 years. The design will adopt a low-maintenance strategy in 
recognition  of  the  limited  capacity  for  maintenance  in  outer  islands,  and  will  include  climate-
proofing measures. 
 
7. 
To  improve  frequent  and  reliable  shipping  services  to  remote  areas,  two  shipping 
support  schemes  will  be  established:  (i)  the  SSS  will  provide  subsidies  for  a  fixed  number  of 
voyages  at  designated  frequencies  on  otherwise  commercially  unviable  routes; 8  and  (ii)  a 
shipping  coordination  scheme  (SCS)  will  appoint  people  in  each  province  to  promote  and 
aggregate  demand,  and  communicate  needs  for  voyages  to  private  sector  vessel  operators. 
The SSS is based on a least-cost tender process for services to be provided by private sector 
operators. Under an output-based approach, subsidies are tied to performance, including vessel 
suitability,  franchise  areas  and  routes,  voyage  locations  and  frequency,  and  substantiation  of 
voyages. Vessels are required to meet safety standards, and carry insurance cover for vessels, 
cargo,  and  passengers.  Subsidies  will  be  reduced  over  time  as  routes  become  commercially 
viable. The support program is scheduled to be implemented over 5 years. 
 
8. 
The  expected  outcome  of  the  current  project  is  that  private  sector  operators  provide 
interisland shipping services that are reliable, safe, and adequately frequent.  Expected outputs 
include  (i)  improved  maritime  infrastructure  in  the  capital  and  rural  areas,  (ii)  establishment  of 
shipping support and coordination schemes, (iii) project management services for efficient and 
effective project implementation, and (iv) establishment of the Office of the Maritime Regulator. 
 
9. 
Project  management  and  implementation.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economic 
Management is the executing agency and the Ministry of Infrastructure and Public Utilities is the 
implementing agency. The government established Vanuatu Project Management Unit (VPMU) 
in  2010  to  manage  all  externally-funded  projects.  VPMU  operates  under  the  oversight  of  the 
Vanuatu  Project  Management  Unit  Steering  Committee  (VPMU-SC)  (Table  4). 9 The  project 
implementation team (PIT), comprising international and national consultants, assists VPMU in 
day-to-day implementation activities. 
 
10.

geotechnical  investigations  in  March  2010,  the  detailed  engineering  designs  are  mostly 
complete  for  the  four  wharves  and  three  jetties,  and  bid  documents  have  been  finalized.  The 
government will deliberate further on the construction of Waisisi wharf because (i) 8 kilometers

17. 
Additional  financing.  The  required  additional  financing  results  from  (i)  a  change  in 
technical  and  design  specifications  and  an  increase  in  the  bill  of  quantities  (BOQ);  (ii)  the

result,  the  overall  project  costs  increased  by  $24.80  million  from  $26.82  million  in  2011  to 
$51.62 million in 2014—a 92% increase. Table 1 summarizes the increase.

21. 
Eligibility  for  additional  financing.  ADB  may  provide  additional  financing  to  projects 
that (i) remain technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound; (ii) are accorded 
high priority by the government; (iii) are consistent with the current project’s objectives; and (iv) 
are consistent with the current country partnership strategy.18 The proposed additional financing 
meets  these  eligibility  criteria.  Technical  soundness  has  been  strengthened  through  the 
additional geotechnical information collected, and the updated economic internal rates of return 
(EIRRs) for all subprojects remain above 12%. The government has confirmed that the overall 
project  is  a  nationally  important  strategic  investment  and  the  current  project’s  development 
objectives remain unchanged. The governments of New Zealand and Vanuatu will also support 
the  project  with  additional  cofinancing  (para.  26).  The  Government  of  Vanuatu’s  Priorities  and 
Action  Agenda,  2006–2015  and  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  Vanuatu,  2010–2014 
both confirm sea transport as a strategic investment priority.19    
 
22.

will  not  meet  its  overall  impact,  outcome  and  outputs.  The  engineering  designs  have  been 
modified to minimize the potential risks from natural disasters. The additional financing will help 
retain most of the original project scope, except Waisisi wharf (para. 10), and meet the outcome 
of the project.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
29.  Wharf  and  jetty  infrastructure  facilities,  channel  dredging,  and  shipping  services  are  at 
various stages of implementation. The design life of the wharves conforms to the current project 
requirements,  current  best  practice,  and  international  codes  and  standards.  The  marine 
structures  have  included  earthquake  and  climate-resilient  design  features  to  remain  fully 
operational  within  the  design  life  period.  Technical  aspects  of  the  design  remain  largely 
unchanged  from  the  current  project,  but  have  been  strengthened  through  geotechnical 
investigations.  Overall,  the  civil  works  under  the  project  remain  technically  feasible.  The  SSS 
and SCS  are  being  implemented  with minor rearrangements,  with  the government’s  SSU  now 
administering  the  shipping  services.  The  subsidized  shipping  service  through  private  sector 
participation commenced in August 2014. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 
 
The  economic  evaluation  of  the  four  wharves  and  three  jetties  was  reassessed. 25 A 
30. 
reassessment of the subprojects shows positive net present values of net benefits, and EIRRs 
for  subprojects  generally  above  the  social  discount  rate  of  12%,  except  for  a  marginal  result 
shown  by  Loltong  wharf.  When  compared  with  the  2010  assessment,  like-for-like  subprojects’ 
economic  indicator  values  have reduced for  all  subprojects. This  was  expected,  as the  capital 
costs of all the subprojects have increased significantly even though some of the increase was 
offset  by  the  combined effect  of  other  updates (e.g.,  use  of  the  correct  social  discount  rate  of 
12%  rather  than the  10%  used earlier,  benefits were  grown to 2014  prices)  introduced for the 
2014  analysis.  To  check  the  acceptability  of  the  economic  outputs  of  the  2014  analysis,  ADB 
carried out an incremental analysis to see how the results varied by changing one parameter at 
a time; it concludes that the reliability of the new results can safely be relied on. 
   
31. 
The  resilience  of  the  net  present  value  of  net  benefits  to  changes  in  key  input 
assumptions for the reappraisal was tested through a number of sensitivity tests. The 30 years 
sensitivity analysis results (EIRRs > 10%) indicate that all the wharves and jetties show strong 
economic  cases  even  with  10%  increase  in  capital  costs  or  10%  decrease  in  benefits.  The 
subprojects also included significant unquantified benefits. 
 
32. 
The conclusions of the financial analysis have not changed since approval. It assumed 
that  the  government  will  impose  modest  charges  for  the  use  of  wharf  in  Port  Vila  but  not 
elsewhere,  and  none  of  these  are  expected  to  operate  on  a  commercial  basis.  The  financial 
internal  rate  of  return  on  civil  works  is,  therefore,  negative,  which  is  acceptable  for  public 
facilities,  particularly  with reasonable EIRRs. The maintenance expenditure forecast for  all  the 
wharves  has  been  estimated  at  $147,000  until  2027.  The  government  has  agreed  to  finance 
these costs and will budget for this starting in 2018. Furthermore, the government is establishing 
a  transport  infrastructure  maintenance  fund  for  the  long-term  sustainability  of  infrastructure 
assets.  During project  implementation,  discussions  with the  Ministry  of Finance  and Economic 
Management  will  take  place  to  ensure  the  asset  register  and  asset  maintenance  plan  will 
provide  the  necessary  information,  and  to  ensure  that  recurrent  budget  funding  for  the 
maintenance  of  newly  constructed  and  repaired  assets  is  allocated  as  part  of  the  budget 
process. 
 

                                                
25 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

C. 

Governance 
 
A financial management assessment was completed as part of the current project.26 The 
33. 
assessment concluded that the overall inherent risk and overall control risk were moderate, and 
proposed  a  number  of  risk  mitigating  measures.  Since  2011,  VPMU  has  the  responsibility  to 
manage  project  funds  and  report  to  financing  partners.  VPMU  is  adequately  staffed  with 
qualified  finance  personnel  and  has  appropriate  financial  management  systems  and  reporting 
mechanisms.  The  project  financial  management  arrangements  established  by  the  government 
through the Department of Finance and Treasury, and VPMU under the oversight of the VPMU-
SC,  are  considered  to  be  operating  effectively,  and  no  change  to  those  arrangements  is 
proposed.  The  main  governance-related  risks,  with  an  emphasis  on  public 
financial 
management and procurement, have been updated.27 
 
34. 
A risk assessment and risk management plan was prepared for the current project. The 
assessment  concluded  that  procurement  and  corruption  risks  are  high,  however  mitigation 
measures are proposed. In addition, a report concluded that procurement remains a key area of 
concern,  in  particular  the  ability  of  the  government  to  ensure that  its  procurement  policies  are 
followed  in  an  equitable,  efficient,  and  transparent  manner. 28 While  the  report  identified  an 
improvement  in  the  availability  of  information  on  procurement  activities,  the  government  is 
addressing  procurement  concerns  with  financial  support  from  the  Government  of  Australia. 
Vanuatu’s score on the World Bank’s governance indicator for control of corruption was +0.45 in 
2012,  which  placed  it  in  the  top  third for  effective control  of  corruption. Vanuatu is the  highest 
ranking  country  in  the  Pacific,  excluding  Australia  and  New  Zealand. 29 ADB’s  Anticorruption 
Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the government under 
the  current  project  and  will  continue to  apply.  Specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 
 
35. 
The  additional  financing  does  not  include  any  additional  works  involving  issues  of 
involuntary  settlement,  indigenous  peoples,  and  gender.  All  civil  works  under  the  additional 
financing will be undertaken at locations that have already been identified and subject to access 
arrangements  prepared  under  the  current  project.  The  resettlement  framework  has  been 
updated.30 Additional documentation on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples is not 
required for the project. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy for the project has 
been updated.31 
  
36. 
The improvement in shipping services for remote rural communities will greatly enhance 
access to essential social services and market opportunities, especially for women. The project 
includes specific features to accommodate women’s needs in constructed or repaired wharves, 
as well as to meet women’s demands for shipping services. The project is proposed for effective 
gender  mainstreaming.  The  GAP  and  its  indicators  in  the  design  and  monitoring  framework 
under the current project remain unchanged and will be applied to the project.

E. 

Safeguards 
 
37. 
The project is classified category C for involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. 
The project is environment category B. Except for Simonsen wharf, the design modifications of 
the  wharves  and  jetties  will  not  result  in  any  environmental  impacts  different  from  those 
described in the approved IEEs because (i) the location and footprint for each wharf remains the 
same; (ii) the increased depth of piles would not create any different impacts from those already 
identified  and  for  which  mitigations  are  proposed;  and  (iii)  the  transportation  of  plant  and 
material, and approximate period of the works (3–6 months at each site) will remain the same. 
Any modifications to wharf designs will be updated in the EMPs and the updated EMPs will be 
included  in  the  bid  documents.  The  project  now  includes  (i) construction  of  Simonsen  wharf 
instead  of  rehabilitation  at  the  same  location,  and  (ii)  a  dredged  channel  in  South  Paray  bay 
(para. 19). The IEE of Simonsen wharf and proposed dredging of the channel will be prepared 
as  outlined  in  the  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  from  the  additional 
financing  funds  to  comply  with  Vanuatu  laws  and  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009), 
including clearance by ADB and the Department of Environment Protection and Conservation. 
 
F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
38. 
The  project  risks  will  continue  to  be  managed  through  mechanisms  established  under 
the current project to ensure that ADB procedures on consultant recruitment, procurement, and 
disbursement are closely followed and project financial accounts are audited. The updated risk 
assessment and risk management plan will be followed. No additional risks are identified.  
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

 
39. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in  the 
updated PAM and loan documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants 
for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement. 
 

V.
